line.token: * Checks the naming of variables and member variables.
* Tokens to ignore so that we can find a DOUBLE_COLON.
* Processes this test, when one of its tokens is encountered.
* @param int $stackPtr The position of the current token in the
// If it's a php reserved var, then its ok.
// Check to see if we are using a variable from an object.
// Either a var name or a function call, so check for bracket.
// There is no way for us to know if the var is public or private,
// so we have to ignore a leading underscore if there is one and just
// check the main part of the variable name.
'Variable "%s" is not in valid camel caps format'
'Variable "%s" contains numbers but this is discouraged'
// There is no way for us to know if the var is public or private,
// so we have to ignore a leading underscore if there is one and just
// check the main part of the variable name.
// The variable lives within a class, and is referenced like
// this: MyClass::$_variable, so we don't know its scope.
'Variable "%s" is not in valid camel caps format'
'Variable "%s" contains numbers but this is discouraged'
* @param int $stackPtr The position of the current token in the
'Public member variable "%s" must not contain a leading underscore'
'%s member variable "%s" must contain a leading underscore'
'Member variable "%s" is not in valid camel caps format'
'Member variable "%s" contains numbers but this is discouraged'
* Processes the variable found within a double quoted string.
* @param int $stackPtr The position of the double quoted
// If it's a php reserved var, then its ok.
'Variable "%s" is not in valid camel caps format'
'Variable "%s" contains numbers but this is discouraged'
